title: 108_hr2630
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commercial Alien Smuggling Elimination Act of 2003" or the "CASE Act of 2003". It introduces a new class of nonimmigrant aliens. The "Commercial Alien Smuggling Elimination Act of 2003" introduces a new class of nonimmigrant aliens who possess critical reliable information about alien smuggling organizations. The "Commercial Alien Smuggling Elimination Act of 2003" introduces a new class of nonimmigrant aliens who possess critical reliable information about alien smuggling organizations and are willing to supply this information to a court. Their presence in the United States is deemed essential for the success of criminal investigations and prosecution. The "Commercial Alien Smuggling Elimination Act of 2003" emphasizes the importance of individuals with critical information about alien smuggling organizations for successful criminal investigations and prosecutions. The Act allows for collaboration between the Secretary of Homeland Security, the Secretary of State, and the Attorney General in addressing these issues. The "Commercial Alien Smuggling Elimination Act of 2003" allows collaboration between the Secretary of Homeland Security, the Secretary of State, and the Attorney General in addressing alien smuggling issues. It amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to limit the number of nonimmigrants under a specific visa category to 400 per fiscal year. The Attorney General can take lawful action to protect the identity of a nonimmigrant or their family member under a specific visa category. Adjustment of status of nonimmigrant to permanent residence is addressed in Section 3. Section 245(j) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include additional criteria for nonimmigrants seeking permanent residence. The Secretary of Homeland Security may adjust the status of an alien to that of an alien lawfully admitted for permanent residence if the alien has provided information that contributed to the success of a commercial alien smuggling investigation, operation disruption, or prosecution, as long as the alien is not described in section 212(a)(3)(E). The Secretary of Homeland Security may adjust the status of a nonimmigrant admitted under a specific section to that of an alien lawfully admitted for permanent residence based on a recommendation from the Secretary of State or the Attorney General. The Secretary of Homeland Security, the Secretary of State, or the Attorney General may take lawful action to protect the identity of a person whose status is adjusted to that of an alien lawfully admitted for permanent residence. SEC. 4. BRINGING IN AND HARBORING CERTAIN ALIENS. Criminal penalties under the Immigration and Nationality Act are increased by up to 10 years for individuals who bring aliens into the US in violation of the law, if the offense is part of a commercial organization, aliens are transported in groups of 10 or more, and their transportation endangers lives or poses health risks. The Immigration and Nationality Act increases criminal penalties for bringing aliens into the US illegally, especially if done by a commercial organization and if the transportation endangers lives or poses health risks. A rewards program is established to assist in combating commercial alien smuggling. The rewards program established under the Immigration and Nationality Act aims to combat commercial alien smuggling involving groups of 10 or more aliens in a manner that endangers lives or poses health risks. It is administered by the Secretary of Homeland Security in consultation with the Attorney General and the Secretary of State. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Attorney General and the Secretary of State, may pay a reward to individuals providing information leading to the arrest or conviction of those involved in commercial alien smuggling of groups of 10 or more aliens. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Attorney General and the Secretary of State, may pay a reward for information leading to the arrest or conviction of individuals involved in commercial alien smuggling of groups of 10 or more aliens, including those endangering lives or posing a health risk. This includes the arrest or conviction of individuals committing, aiding, or abetting such acts, as well as the prevention or frustration of these activities. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Attorney General and the Secretary of State, may pay a reward for information leading to the arrest or conviction of individuals involved in commercial alien smuggling of groups of 10 or more aliens, including those endangering lives or posing a health risk. This includes the dismantling of alien smuggling organizations and identifying key leaders in these operations. The transportation of aliens in groups of 10 or more must not endanger their lives or pose a life-threatening health risk to people in the United States. Authorization of appropriations is available for carrying out this subsection. Officers or employees of any government are ineligible if involved in such activities. The paragraph states that an officer or employee of any government who provides information while on duty is not eligible for a reward. Protection measures are in place to safeguard the identity of individuals who provide information. The paragraph outlines that rewards for providing information are limited to $100,000 unless authorized by the Secretary of Homeland Security. Measures are in place to protect the identity of individuals providing information. The Secretary of Homeland Security can authorize larger rewards if necessary to combat alien smuggling operations endangering lives or posing health risks in the United States. The Secretary of Homeland Security can approve rewards exceeding $50,000 to combat alien smuggling operations that endanger lives or pose health risks in the United States. Any reward granted must be certified for payment by the Secretary of Homeland Security. Additionally, an outreach program is established under Section 274 of the Immigration and Nationality Act to address these issues. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Attorney General and the Secretary of State, will develop an outreach program to educate the public about penalties for bringing in and harboring aliens, as well as the rewards for assisting in investigations or prosecutions. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Attorney General and the Secretary of State, will develop an outreach program to educate the public about penalties for assisting in the investigation, disruption, or prosecution of a commercial smuggling operation.
